Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with couchant lion with sun-disc above back; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; glazed surface surviving as thin buff to greenish layer in some parts; yellowish core, with porous, rough texture; surface quite eroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions, with the specific motif displayed on this scaraboid being found on several examples and notably in the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45, see especially 44 as a close parallel for this piece). This scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A72a). For a similar scaraboid: BM 1886,0401.1627. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, nos 42-45, esp. 44) (not an exact parallel, but clearly the same group)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.005) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, chipped in places and surface eroded
